Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Ordering Process in Water, Aqueous Solutions, and Water-Biomolecule Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms Program supports the collaborative efforts of Pablo G. Debenedetti (Princeton University), C. Austen Angell (Arizona State University), and H. Eugene Stanley (Boston University). Their goal is to understand cooperative phenomena in water, aqueous solutions and water-biomolecule systems. Cooperative processes involve the sudden and concerted participation of a large number of basic units: amino acid residues in protein folding, proteins in fibrilization, small molecules in first-order phase transitions, or complex molecules in self-assembly. This collaboration will involve (I) experimental and computational studies of phase transitions in supercooled network-forming liquids of broad materials science interest; (II) experimental studies of the control of protein refolding by solvent tuning; (III) computer simulations of protein refolding rates and their control by protonation/deprotonation and solvent tuning; and (IV) computational investigations of the kinetics of water capillary evaporation in nano-scale hydrophobic confinement.

The topics addressed in this project have implications that go far beyond their inherent scientific interest. These include the long-term storage and preservation of therapeutic drugs (proposed studies of protein refolding), the molecular mechanisms of neurodegenerative diseases (proposed studies of protein refolding), the design of advanced materials by self-assembly (proposed studies of capillary evaporation), the development of advanced materials for optical communications (proposed studies of phase transitions in molten silica) and the development of new proteins with improved stability characteristics in non-aqueous environments (proposed studies of protein refolding). The project will also provide opportunities for undergraduates, graduate students, and postdoctoral researchers to integrate experiment and computation and work in a team at the interface of chemistry, physics, engineering and biology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project has been to understand so-called cooperative phenomena in water, aqueous solutions and systems composed of water and biomolecules. Cooperative processes involve the sudden and concerted participation of a large number of basic units: amino acids in protein folding, proteins in fibrilization, small molecules in first-order phase transitions, or complex molecules in self-assembly. The main outcomes of this project are listed below.

 

(1) Using advanced molecular simulation computational techniques, we showed that a widely-used model of water separates into two distinct liquid phases at low temperatures. This result is relevant to the behavior of water in the atmosphere, where it can exist as a so-called supercooled liquid below its freezing point.

 

(2) In a complementary experimental study, we investigated mixtures of protic ionic liquids in water. Such systems possess the remarkable properties of suppressing ice crystallization while at the same time preserving cold water’s characteristic anomalies, such as the fact that it expands when cooled. We observed in such systems a striking increase in heat capacity upon cooling, which can be fully reversed upon heating. This observation is consistent with the presence of a phase transition between two liquids, such as we found in the above-cited computational studies.

 

(3) Using advanced molecular simulation computational techniques, we performed the first direct calculation of the rate at which ice forms from liquid water at conditions prevalent in high-altitude clouds.

 

(4) When two oily surfaces that repel water approach sufficiently closely, liquid water is expelled, leaving behind a vapor phase. This phenomenon is believed to be important in protein folding and in the formation of biological membranes. Using thermodynamic theory, we showed that surface flexibility can significantly facilitate water evaporation. Previous analyses of this phenomenon failed to take into account the importance of surface flexibility.

 

(5) We showed that a simple spherical model with two characteristic length scales, commonly-referred to as Jagla model, is able to reproduce the distinctive thermodynamic characteristics of real liquid water as a solvent for both small and large molecules. The finding that two competing length scales suffice to reveal signature behavior thought to be specific to water is an important result from the point of view of fundamental understanding of the physical chemistry of water.

 

(6) We investigated by molecular simulation two popular models of the archetypal glass former, silica. We found that the diffusivity is a good indicator of how close a liquid is to a critical point, and identified geometric criteria that would need to be satisfied by modified versions of the models in order for it to exhibit a liquid-liquid transition.
